author: jochembrouwer
content: To be honest, the simplicity argument does not work for me. We now have two opcodes which do exactly the same as other opcodes (DUP1-DUP16 / SWAP1-SWAP16). It is super likely that compilers will use the original opcodes because it saves an deployment byte. We will thus see, in practice, that the DUPN1-16 and SWAPN1-16 are (almost) never deployed, which I think would be a waste of bytecode space ðŸ˜…

author: chfast
content: Yes, this is likely. There is 0 point for using DUPN[0].

author: demiurgos_23
content: guys, what are the clients passing all tests, I'd like to run some locally and compare some traces xD (Create opcodes and ExtCall opcodes tests failing for us)

author: big_tech_sux
content: It was originally a forwards compatibility issue (like if we want to phase out the old DUP opcodes, its easier if the new DUPN opcodes exist since then the semantics dont need to be changed). But since <@403707149043105803> explained to me one of the design goals of new eof is the ability to automatically upgrade code in place to a new version of eof if needed, I'm neutral on the issue.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Fine, but DUPN[0] or DUPN[1] does not make sense since we already have opcodes for that

author: draganrakita
content: My not strong opinion, If DUP1..16 are present DUPN should start from 17.

author: _shemnon
content: DUP1-16 has the advantage of less bytes.  If we start dupn and swapn at 17 then that makes reclaiming those opcodes more difficult.
